results.title: Gulf Country
results.brief_description: The country in Northern Australia bordering on the Gulf of Carpentaria is a flat, dry area in which the rivers and creeks seldom run and isolated water holes keep the wild life and stock alive. At the time when gold was being mined there several townships were flourishing but these are largely abandoned. The Anglican run Mitchell River Mission is located here. At the waterholes may be seen large flocks of ibis and many other birds as well as wild pigs and crocodiles. At times the sky is darkened by flights of flying foxes.

results.title: Guinea gold
results.brief_description: This film presents the early history of the Bulolo goldfields in the northwestern part of what is known today as the Territory of Papua New Guinea. The gold prospectors were the explorers of this rugged country mandated to Australia by the League of Nations. The film records primitive native life of the area as it was discovered by them - a people with unique customs living in a stone-age environment. Shows the discovery of alluvial gold in the Bulolo Valley and the construction of the first dredges, every part of which was flown in three tons at a time over the mountains from Lae in three-engined Junkers aircraft. The role of the aircraft is shown to be basic in the development of the resources of the Bulolo Valley, and the valley itself with its wealth of alluvial gold was a basic part of the economic and industrial development of pre-war New Guinea.

results.title: Guilty chimneys
results.brief_description: Deals with the urgent problem of smoke-abatement. The film shows how smoking coal fires not only waste fuel, but also cause dirt and corrosion, and bring about fogs and illness. Various methods of smoke-elimination in the home and industry are outlined, in particular the wider use of gas and coke; and the establishment of new smokeless zone together with extension of existing ones is advocated.

results.title: Guiding the growth of children
results.creator_credit: George L. George and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Planning for Teaching”.
Shows that developing the pupil as an individual is the most important part of the teacher’s job. A teacher tells how she dealt with a number of cases of “problem children”, by an individual approach in each case. These children include a poor reader, a shy girl, a bully, and clown, a stutterer and a pupil with a very hight IQ.

results.title: The Guide log
results.creator_credit: Bill Latto and Town and Country Productions
results.brief_description: The story of the Girl Guides Association from the enrolment of a Brownie to the work of the Trefoil Guild or Senior Branch. Explains the work and play of the movement: social work, camping, cooking, keeping house, sailing, gliding, etc. Sequences include national dances performed by participation in an international guide camp.

results.title: Who's responsible?
results.creator_credit: Robert Sande and JW Newman Corp
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Guidance for the 70’s”.
I am the cause of my own effects. This is a difficult concept for many to accept; most people prefer to “blame” others or environment for what happens to them. Teenagers attending a PACE conference deal with the concept of responsibility. Their discussions highlight how ‘what happens to you is under your own control to a very great extent’ and that, by exercising your choice, you can ‘create the effect your want to have in your life’.

results.title: Putting yourself together
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Guidance for the 70’s”.
Two teenagers and counsellor Daniel Whiteside take a close look at how to think your way past the put-downs or problems that often weaken your self-image. The give-and-take between the three, draws us into the film and challenges us all to start taking control of this part of our lives.

results.title: Kids, parents and pressures
results.creator_credit: Robert Sande, Bailey Film Productions and Robert Sande Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Guidance for the 70’s”.
Teenagers attending a PACE Seminar identify some of the everyday pressures and tensions that confront them. With the help of highly qualified instructors, they learn they are in control of their own attitudes and work out positive and effective ways of improving their attitudes and relieving pressures.
